NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit in a steady or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded than people have come unexpectedly (that is, was the term to "take potlatch" used, or was some other expression commented upon)?

Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst drives or dances in homes?

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks once a month, etc.?

PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, FARMERS, ETC.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit in the morning or other days?

4. What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

Was the invitation to a meal worded than people had come unexpectedly?

That is, was the term to make potlucks used, or was other opportunity common?

Did you ever have "tea" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what "tea" was for, and how often they occurred.

Did you ever have "tea" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, what drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Here these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pictures, etc.)

School was the only place in the valley for hall parties.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. What was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? Describe.

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipally, some organization, etc.? Describe.

Has it been enlarged since then?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Note: Do not recount answers of other people.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree planting, etc.)

School was used for the annual dance in the winter.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

They were attracted to school because of the school's location.

9. How was your first community hall built?

That material was it made of? Describe.

The building was constructed by volunteers.

Has it been enlarged since then? If so, describe how.

It has not been enlarged since then.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as related to question 6, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

Yes, families and small children provided for.

Was there card playing for a prize?

Yes, there was card playing for a prize.

What dances were popular?

Square dances, waltz, polka.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

No, there was no disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Card playing was accepted by all residents in the community.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Bridge, whist, pinochle, canasta.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet? Price a month?

What were some of the activities carried out by this organization?

17. Was there a women's club in your district? If so, what was its name?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

The women were mostly poor and hardworking. They particularly needed money for their families and children. I remember recalling the difficulties and often needing help and support from the farmers. In particular, they were very helpful.
